title: Peter Vaughan
text:
Peter Vaughan (born Peter Ewart Ohm; 4 April 1923 – 6 December 2016) was an English <a href="character%20actor">character actor</a> known for many supporting roles in British film and television productions. He also acted extensively on the stage.
He is perhaps best known for his role as <a href="Characters%20of%20Porridge%20%28TV%20series%29%23Harry%20Grout">Grouty</a> in the sitcom "<a href="Porridge%20%28TV%20series%29">Porridge</a>" and its <a href="Porridge%20%28film%29">1979 film adaptation</a>. Other parts included a recurring role alongside <a href="Robert%20Lindsay%20%28actor%29">Robert Lindsay</a> in the sitcom "<a href="Citizen%20Smith">Citizen Smith</a>", Tom Hedden in "<a href="Straw%20Dogs%20%281971%20film%29">Straw Dogs</a>", Winston the Ogre in "<a href="Time%20Bandits">Time Bandits</a>", Tom Franklin in "<a href="Chancer">Chancer</a>" and Mr. Stevens, Sr. in "<a href="The%20Remains%20of%20the%20Day%20%28film%29">The Remains of the Day</a>". His final role was as <a href="List%20of%20A%20Song%20of%20Ice%20and%20Fire%20characters%23Maester%20Aemon">Maester Aemon</a> in <a href="HBO">HBO</a>'s "<a href="Game%20of%20Thrones">Game of Thrones</a>" (2011–2015).
Early life.
Vaughan was born Peter Ewart Ohm on 4 April 1923 in <a href="Wem">Wem</a>, <a href="Shropshire">Shropshire</a>, the son of a bank clerk, Max Ohm, who was an <a href="Austrians">Austrian</a> immigrant, and Eva Wright, a nurse. The family later moved to <a href="Wellington%2C%20Shropshire">Wellington</a>, in the same county, where he began his schooling. Vaughan said that while reciting a poem at infant school in Wellington he first experienced the applause and admiration coming from a good performance. From the age of seven he lived in <a href="Staffordshire">Staffordshire</a>, where he attended <a href="Uttoxeter%20Grammar%20School">Uttoxeter Grammar School</a>.
After leaving school, Vaughan joined <a href="Wolverhampton">the Wolverhampton</a> <a href="Repertory%20theatre">Repertory Theatre</a>, and gained experience in other repertory theatres as well, before <a href="British%20Army">army</a> service during the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a>. He was commissioned a <a href="second%20lieutenant">second lieutenant</a> in the <a href="Royal%20Corps%20of%20Signals">Royal Corps of Signals</a> on 9 June 1943, and served in <a href="Normandy">Normandy</a>, <a href="Belgium">Belgium</a>, and the <a href="Far%20East">Far East</a>. At the end of the war, Vaughan was in <a href="Singapore">Singapore</a> during the liberation of <a href="Changi%20Prison">Changi Prison</a>.
Career.
Vaughan made his film debut in 1959 in an uncredited role as a police officer in "<a href="The%2039%20Steps%20%281959%20film%29">The 39 Steps</a>". He continued for several years to play small parts, including more cameos as policemen in "<a href="Village%20of%20the%20Damned%20%281960%20film%29">Village of the Damned</a>" and "<a href="The%20Victors%20%281963%20film%29">The Victors</a>," before gaining his first starring role, in a minor picture called "<a href="Smokescreen%20%28film%29">Smokescreen</a>" (1964), where he played an insurance assessor investigating a businessman’s disappearance in one of the last, and best, of the old-style British <a href="B-movies">B-movies</a>. In 1967, he received second billing opposite <a href="Frank%20Sinatra">Frank Sinatra</a> in the film "<a href="The%20Naked%20Runner">The Naked Runner</a>". His performance was not well received by critics who accused him of overacting in his role as a British agent. He played Mr. Freeman in <a href="Karel%20Reisz">Karel Reisz</a>'s 1980 "<a href="The%20French%20Lieutenant%27s%20Woman%20%28film%29">The French Lieutenant's Woman</a>", alongside <a href="Meryl%20Streep">Meryl Streep</a> and <a href="Jeremy%20Irons">Jeremy Irons</a>.
Possibly Vaughan’s highest-profile film performance was as the father of <a href="Anthony%20Hopkins">Anthony Hopkins</a>'s character in "<a href="The%20Remains%20of%20the%20Day%20%28film%29">The Remains of the Day</a>" (1993). He was also cast in <a href="Terry%20Gilliam">Terry Gilliam</a>'s "<a href="The%20Man%20Who%20Killed%20Don%20Quixote">The Man Who Killed Don Quixote</a>", but had not shot any material before that project was abandoned. He had previously appeared for Gilliam in "<a href="Time%20Bandits">Time Bandits</a>" and "<a href="Brazil%20%281985%20film%29">Brazil</a>". Vaughan appeared as a menacing character in "<a href="Straw%20Dogs%20%281971%20film%29">Straw Dogs</a>" (1971), and with Bill Murray in a film of <a href="W.%20Somerset%20Maugham">W. Somerset Maugham</a>'s novel "<a href="The%20Razor%27s%20Edge%20%281984%20film%29">The Razor's Edge</a>" in 1984. In 1996, he appeared as <a href="Giles%20Corey">Giles Corey</a> in "<a href="The%20Crucible%20%281996%20film%29">The Crucible</a>", and in 1997 he appeared alongside <a href="Robert%20Carlyle">Robert Carlyle</a> and <a href="Ray%20Winstone">Ray Winstone</a> in "<a href="Face%20%281997%20film%29">Face</a>". In 1998, Vaughan played <a href="Bishop%20Myriel">Bishop Myriel</a> in "<a href="Les%20Mis%C3%A9rables%20%281998%20film%29">Les Misérables</a>," alongside <a href="Liam%20Neeson">Liam Neeson</a>. His most unusual role may have been as <a href="SS">SS</a> <a href="Obergruppenf%C3%BChrer">Obergruppenführer</a> <a href="Arthur%20Nebe">Arthur Nebe</a> in the 1994 film of <a href="Robert%20Harris%20%28novelist%29">Robert Harris'</a>s novel "<a href="Fatherland%20%281994%20film%29">Fatherland</a>".
He appeared in the music video for <a href="Kate%20Bush">Kate Bush</a>'s song "<a href="Experiment%20IV">Experiment IV</a>".
Television.
Vaughan became known for his performances on television, including supporting roles in "<a href="Porridge%20%28TV%20series%29">Porridge</a>" (as <a href="Harry%20Grout">"Genial" Harry Grout</a>) and "<a href="Citizen%20Smith">Citizen Smith</a>" as Charles Johnson (his role in the latter series was taken over by <a href="Tony%20Steedman">Tony Steedman</a>). His role in "Porridge" brought him a great deal of public recognition despite his character appearing in only three episodes and in the <a href="Porridge%20%28film%29">1979 film</a> of the series.
In 1975, he appeared as Tony Kirby in an episode of the hard hitting police drama "<a href="The%20Sweeney">The Sweeney</a>" entitled "Stay Lucky, Eh?"
He also appeared as "The Fence" in the well known humorous advert for McVities Fruit Shortcake biscuits along with Harry Fowler.
In 1969, Vaughan appeared in "<a href="Randall%20and%20Hopkirk%20%28Deceased%29">Randall and Hopkirk</a>" in the episode "<a href="Never%20Trust%20a%20Ghost">Never Trust a Ghost</a>". In the same year, he starred in the thirteen-part <a href="London%20Weekend%20Television">London Weekend Television</a> TV series "The Gold Robbers". In December 1972, he appeared as Mr. Paxton in the BBC television adaptation of the <a href="M.R.%20James">M.R. James</a> ghost story "<a href="A%20Warning%20to%20the%20Curious">A Warning to the Curious</a>", shown as part of their annual series "<a href="A%20Ghost%20Story%20for%20Christmas">A Ghost Story for Christmas</a>".' In September 1973, he appeared as Quinn in the <a href="London%20Weekend%20Television">London Weekend Television</a> TV series The Protectors, in an episode called 'Quinn'. 
Vaughan starred as Billy Fox in the <a href="Thames%20Television">Thames Television</a> series "<a href="Fox%20%28TV%20series%29">Fox</a>" (1980). The saga was written by <a href="Trevor%20Preston">Trevor Preston</a>, directed by <a href="Jim%20Goddard">Jim Goddard</a>, and produced by <a href="Verity%20Lambert">Verity Lambert</a>. Other Fox family members were played by <a href="Elizabeth%20Spriggs">Elizabeth Spriggs</a>, <a href="Ray%20Winstone">Ray Winstone</a>, <a href="Larry%20Lamb">Larry Lamb</a>, and <a href="Bernard%20Hill">Bernard Hill</a>. Historical roles Vaughan played include those of Russian foreign minister <a href="Alexander%20Izvolsky">Alexander Izvolsky</a> in the serial "<a href="Fall%20of%20Eagles">Fall of Eagles</a>" (1974), British politician <a href="Thomas%20Inskip">Thomas Inskip</a> in the mini-series ' (1981), the title role in "A Last Visitor for Mr. <a href="Hugh%20Peter">Hugh Peter</a>" (1981), and German Nazi figures <a href="Kurt%20Zeitzler">Kurt Zeitzler</a> in the miniseries "<a href="War%20and%20Remembrance%20%28miniseries%29">War and Remembrance</a>" (1988) and <a href="Hermann%20G%C3%B6ring">Hermann Göring</a> in the <a href="ITV%20Granada">Granada Television</a>-<a href="Public%20Broadcasting%20Service">PBS</a> docu-drama "<a href="Countdown%20to%20War">Countdown to War</a>" (1989). He also appeared in many literary adaptations, such as "<a href="Bleak%20House%20%281985%20TV%20serial%29">Bleak House</a>" (BBC, 1985), in which he played the sinister lawyer Mr. Tulkinghorn, and "<a href="Our%20Mutual%20Friend">Our Mutual Friend</a>" (BBC Two, 1998). Other television work includes the espionage thriller ' (1988), in a lead role as the head of the <a href="KGB">KGB</a>.
In 1986, Vaughan appeared in the <a href="music%20video">promotional video</a> for <a href="Kate%20Bush">Kate Bush</a>'s "<a href="Experiment%20IV">Experiment IV</a>" single. In 1991, he played John Turner in an episode of <a href="ITV%20Granada">Granada Television</a>'s "<a href="The%20Adventures%20of%20Sherlock%20Holmes%20%28TV%20series%29">The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes</a>" titled '"<a href="The%20Boscombe%20Valley%20Mystery">The Boscombe Valley Mystery</a>".
He also appeared in the BBC production of Alan Aykbourn's play 'Season's Greetings' which was broadcast at Christmas 1986, and repeated on BBC 2 some years later. He played the role of Uncle Harvey.
Vaughan later attained particular acclaim for his supporting role as the <a href="Alzheimer%27s%20disease">Alzheimer's</a> sufferer Felix Hutchinson in "<a href="Our%20Friends%20in%20the%20North">Our Friends in the North</a>" (<a href="BBC%20Two">BBC Two</a>, 1996), a role that garnered a Best Actor nomination at the 1997 <a href="British%20Academy%20Television%20Awards">British Academy Television Awards</a>. He played the clockmaker <a href="George%20Graham%20%28clockmaker%29">George Graham</a> in "<a href="Longitude%20%28TV%20series%29">Longitude</a>", the TV drama adaptation of <a href="Dava%20Sobel">Dava Sobel</a>'s eponymous non-fiction novel about the quest for a means to determine longitude at sea.
In 2007 he starred in the television series "<a href="Mobile%20%28TV%20series%29">Mobile</a>," and as Uncle Alfie in the film "<a href="Death%20at%20a%20Funeral%20%282007%20film%29">Death at a Funeral</a>".
In 2011 Vaughan starred as Michael Dodd in the BBC courtroom drama "<a href="Silk%20%28TV%20series%29">Silk</a>". His final role, between 2011 and 2015, was <a href="Maester%20Aemon">Maester Aemon</a> in the <a href="HBO">HBO</a> series "<a href="Game%20of%20Thrones">Game of Thrones</a>".
Radio.
Vaughan was heard as Superintendent Kirk in the BBC dramatisation of <a href="Dorothy%20L.%20Sayers">Dorothy L. Sayers</a>' Peter Wimsey novel "Busman's Honeymoon", and as <a href="Denethor">Denethor</a> in the 1981 <a href="BBC%20Radio">BBC Radio</a> production of "<a href="The%20Lord%20of%20the%20Rings%20%281981%20radio%20series%29">The Lord of the Rings</a>". He played <a href="Charles%20Augustus%20Milverton">Charles Augustus Milverton</a> in a 1993 BBC radio dramatization of the <a href="Sherlock%20Holmes">Sherlock Holmes</a> short story.
Stage.
Vaughan's first breakout role was in 1964 as Ed in <a href="Joe%20Orton">Joe Orton</a>'s work "<a href="Entertaining%20Mr%20Sloane">Entertaining Mr Sloane</a>" performed at <a href="Wyndham%27s%20Theatre">Wyndham's Theatre</a>.
Personal life and death.
The first of Vaughan's two marriages was to <a href="Billie%20Whitelaw">Billie Whitelaw</a>, whom he married in 1952 and divorced in 1966. His second wife was actress Lillias Walker, with whom he lived in the village of <a href="Mannings%20Heath">Mannings Heath</a>, in <a href="West%20Sussex">West Sussex</a>, until his death, having previously lived in <a href="Crawley">Crawley</a>. His stepdaughter Victoria Burton (actress and producer) is married to <a href="Gregor%20Fisher">Gregor Fisher</a>.
Vaughan was partially blind in his old age. On 6 December 2016, he died peacefully of natural causes at the age of 93.
